Columbia Professor Dr. James Yardley and Graduate Students Speak About Nanotechnology

May 2, 2011

Columbia Professor Dr. James Yardley and Graduate Students Speak About Nanotechnology

By KAREN ZHENG ⋅ May 2, 2011 ⋅ Post a comment

Columbia University professor of electrical engineering Dr. James Yardley and six graduate students came to Stuyvesant to speak to two Honors Physics classes on Monday, March 28, to discuss the advances nanotechnology can make in everyday life. The visit was prompted by NanoDays, a nationwide program sponsored by the Nanoscale Informal Science Education network that brings researchers in nanotechnology into high schools.

Columbia University’s Nanoscale Science and Engineering Center (NSEC) contacted a number of New York City high schools known for science education and a strong minority student body. Six schools were selected to receive a presentation on the basics of nanotechnology, an introduction to the research being conducted at the Columbia Nanocenter, and everyday and future applications of nanotechnology.

Last year, 80 Stuyvesant students attended NanoDay, an annual event at the City College of New York (CCNY) that includes lectures and demonstrations about nanotechnology. However, this was the first year that speakers requested to come to Stuyvesant. Assistant Principal Chemistry and Physics Scott Thomas readily accepted their offer.

“Professors give students an opportunity to get an idea of what’s happening in a college environment in terms of research,” Thomas said.

Yardley and the six Columbia, CCNY, and Barnard College graduate students—Salima Bahri, Arun Batra, Colin Cunningham, Max Roberts, Vincent Lee, and Yu Zhao—visited physics teachers Rebecca Gorla’s fifth period class and Honorio Esper’s third period class. They started off their presentation by defining nanotechnology, the branch of technology that deals with objects with dimensions of less than one hundred nanometers. A nanometer is one billionth of a meter, a scale that is often difficult to fathom. To aid students, the lecturers contrasted the micro-scale world of one micrometer to one-millimeter-long objects—which include dust mites, fly ashes, and red blood cells—to the nano-scale world impossible to observe with optical microscopy—which includes atoms and deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA). They also described NSEC, Columbia’s research center for nano-systems.

“It made me more interested in science, especially nanotechnology. I learned a lot about nanotechnology and the different uses of it,” junior Hema Lochan said. “I wasn’t sure what jobs are out there in physics, and the presentation showed me one.”

The speakers showcased everyday applications of nanotechnology with the example of ferrofluids—liquids that are polarized when in the presence of a magnetic field, which can be used to reduce friction between a magnet and a surface and form seals in sensitive electronic devices—and carbon nanotubes, which can act as conductors of light in television screens and extra energy storage space in batteries. In the future, nanotechnology research may produce materials capable of seeking out and destroying cancer cells, stronger and more conductive materials, faster and smaller computational devices, and new photovoltaic materials that convert solar radiation into electricity.

Yardley and the graduate students made their presentation interactive by including demonstrations. “We created a plasma speaker that utilized the principle of field emission to generate a spark that was modulated by music. That is, we created a scaled down version of lightening and thunder and then controlled it to create tones and play music from an iPod,” Baltra said in an e-mail interview.

They hoped that this would not only garner students’ interest, but also help them grasp the complex concepts explained. “We showed how natural phenomena can be scaled down and controlled to turn science into technology, which is a basic principle of nanotechnology,” Batra said in an e-mail interview. “Demos are a great way to show students that what they learn in books is actually real. We try to convey the thinking behind certain inventions and break down obscure ideas into simple terms.”

Following the demo, students were given the opportunity to ask questions. “The students seemed very responsive and asked excellent questions,” Yardley said in an e-mail interview.

Junior Yiru Luo agreed with Yardley’s evaluation. “The presentation made me consider going to Columbia to learn more about the things that they showed us,” Luo said. “Getting to see how science actually works was definitely very valuable.”

“It was very informative and very motivating. I would like to have future speakers,” Gorla said. “The students got to see a more exciting aspect of physics: the use of nanotechnology. Now they have more of a reason to want to learn.”
